I had the opportunity at beyond the ballot program to speak about something that matters deeply , the role of women and youth in shaping the political future of Sri Lanka.

"Women make up more than 50% of our population, yet their presence in politics remains far too low. If we truly believe in democracy, then we must also believe that leadership should reflect the people. And that means giving space, support, and encouragement for more women to step into political roles. Talent has no gender and when women lead, communities thrive.

At the same time, we as young people have a responsibility. We can't keep blaming the system if weâ€™re not willing to be part of the change. Politics isnâ€™t just about power,  itâ€™s about service. If we want better policies, better futures, and real representation, then we must step up, speak out, and get involved.

Change begins when we stop waiting for others and start becoming the voice that drives it."

I had the opportunity at beyond the ballot program to speak about something that matters deeply , the role of women and youth in shaping the political future of Sri Lanka.

"Women make up more than 50% of our population, yet their presence in politics remains far too low. If we truly believe in democracy, then we must also believe that leadership should reflect the people. And that means giving space, support, and encouragement for more women to step into political roles. Talent has no gender and when women lead, communities thrive.

At the same time, we as young people have a responsibility. We can't keep blaming the system if weâ€™re not willing to be part of the change. Politics isnâ€™t just about power,  itâ€™s about service. If we want better policies, better futures, and real representation, then we must step up, speak out, and get involved.

Change begins when we stop waiting for others and start becoming the voice that drives it."

JAFFNA, Sri Lankaâ€”Itâ€™s been a busy few months at the polls for Sri Lanka, which recently capped off its third set of elections in under eight months, capped by local elections held on May 6. The voting determined the makeup of local councils across the island, and the outcomes signaled that while President Anura Kumara Dissanayake continues to enjoy popular support, his honeymoon period may be nearing its end.â 
â 
The series of polls began last September, when Dissanayakeâ€”popularly known as AKDâ€”swept to power on a lasting wave of discontent following the collapse of Sri Lankaâ€™s economy in 2022. That crisis saw the country default on its international debt amid soaring cost-of-living conditions and a currency collapse, leading to public protests that unseated then-President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.â 
â 
As the longtime leader of the traditionally marginalized leftist party Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, or JVP, Dissanayake was perceived as a political outsider, positioning him well in the runup to the first presidential election since the 2022 protests, known as the Aragalaya movement. His JVP-led National Peopleâ€™s Power, or NPP, alliance subsequently earned a supermajority in Novemberâ€™s parliamentary elections, winning 159 seats out of 225 on 62 percent of the vote.â 
â 
In the local elections held earlier this month, the NPP still won the largest vote share, taking over councils in the Sinhala heartlands and upcountry areas. But it fell to 43 percent overall, raising the question of where Dissanayakeâ€™s NPP government stands after six months in power.â 
â 
Read more at the link in bio.â

JAFFNA, Sri Lankaâ€”Itâ€™s been a busy few months at the polls for Sri Lanka, which recently capped off its third set of elections in under eight months, capped by local elections held on May 6. The voting determined the makeup of local councils across the island, and the outcomes signaled that while President Anura Kumara Dissanayake continues to enjoy popular support, his honeymoon period may be nearing its end.â 
â 
The series of polls began last September, when Dissanayakeâ€”popularly known as AKDâ€”swept to power on a lasting wave of discontent following the collapse of Sri Lankaâ€™s economy in 2022. That crisis saw the country default on its international debt amid soaring cost-of-living conditions and a currency collapse, leading to public protests that unseated then-President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.â 
â 
As the longtime leader of the traditionally marginalized leftist party Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, or JVP, Dissanayake was perceived as a political outsider, positioning him well in the runup to the first presidential election since the 2022 protests, known as the Aragalaya movement. His JVP-led National Peopleâ€™s Power, or NPP, alliance subsequently earned a supermajority in Novemberâ€™s parliamentary elections, winning 159 seats out of 225 on 62 percent of the vote.â 
â 
In the local elections held earlier this month, the NPP still won the largest vote share, taking over councils in the Sinhala heartlands and upcountry areas. But it fell to 43 percent overall, raising the question of where Dissanayakeâ€™s NPP government stands after six months in power.â 
â 
Read more at the link in bio.â 
â

JAFFNA, Sri Lankaâ€”Itâ€™s been a busy few months at the polls for Sri Lanka, which recently capped off its third set of elections in under eight months, capped by local elections held on May 6. The voting determined the makeup of local councils across the island, and the outcomes signaled that while President Anura Kumara Dissanayake continues to enjoy popular support, his honeymoon period may be nearing its end.â 
â 
The series of polls began last September, when Dissanayakeâ€”popularly known as AKDâ€”swept to power on a lasting wave of discontent following the collapse of Sri Lankaâ€™s economy in 2022. That crisis saw the country default on its international debt amid soaring cost-of-living conditions and a currency collapse, leading to public protests that unseated then-President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.â 
â 
As the longtime leader of the traditionally marginalized leftist party Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, or JVP, Dissanayake was perceived as a political outsider, positioning him well in the runup to the first presidential election since the 2022 protests, known as the Aragalaya movement. His JVP-led National Peopleâ€™s Power, or NPP, alliance subsequently earned a supermajority in Novemberâ€™s parliamentary elections, winning 159 seats out of 225 on 62 percent of the vote.â 
â 
In the local elections held earlier this month, the NPP still won the largest vote share, taking over councils in the Sinhala heartlands and upcountry areas. But it fell to 43 percent overall, raising the question of where Dissanayakeâ€™s NPP government stands after six months in power.â 
â

JAFFNA, Sri Lankaâ€”Itâ€™s been a busy few months at the polls for Sri Lanka, which recently capped off its third set of elections in under eight months, capped by local elections held on May 6. The voting determined the makeup of local councils across the island, and the outcomes signaled that while President Anura Kumara Dissanayake continues to enjoy popular support, his honeymoon period may be nearing its end.â 
â 
The series of polls began last September, when Dissanayakeâ€”popularly known as AKDâ€”swept to power on a lasting wave of discontent following the collapse of Sri Lankaâ€™s economy in 2022. That crisis saw the country default on its international debt amid soaring cost-of-living conditions and a currency collapse, leading to public protests that unseated then-President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.â 
â 
As the longtime leader of the traditionally marginalized leftist party Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, or JVP, Dissanayake was perceived as a political outsider, positioning him well in the runup to the first presidential election since the 2022 protests, known as the Aragalaya movement. His JVP-led National Peopleâ€™s Power, or NPP, alliance subsequently earned a supermajority in Novemberâ€™s parliamentary elections, winning 159 seats out of 225 on 62 percent of the vote.â 
â 
In the local elections held earlier this month, the NPP still won the largest vote share, taking over councils in the Sinhala heartlands and upcountry areas. But it fell to 43 percent overall, raising the question of where Dissanayakeâ€™s NPP government stands after six months in power.â 
â 
Read more at the link in bio.â

While the Wickremesinghe government won plaudits abroad for its handling of the economic crisis, at home the language of the National Peopleâ€™s Power resonated with a population increasingly disgruntled by the austerity measures put in place to combat it.

The result is that at parliamentary elections in November, all the countryâ€™s districts bar one gave the National Peopleâ€™s Power sweeping and respectable majorities â€“ more or less giving the lie to Wickremesingheâ€™s claims of having achieved economic and political stability under his watch.

This is a two-part article on the implications of Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s arrest.

Read the full piece on Scroll.in (Link in BIO/IG STORIES)

#RanilWickremsinghe #ranilwickremsinghearrest #srilankapolitics

Wickremesinghe was brought before a commission in the late 1990s over the torture camp allegations, but nothing came out of it. The National Peopleâ€™s Power made several insinuations about the Rajapaksas stealing money in the run-up to last yearâ€™s elections, but members of the family have not yet been questioned about them.

The National Peopleâ€™s Power can claim, not unjustifiably, that those allegations were swept under the carpet â€“ a crucial part of their anti-elite discourse. Yet, even considering this, it seems plausible that if they are not proven, or if they end up nowhere, or if the economy falters while the National Peopleâ€™s Power pursues these cases, the allegations will end up re-legitimising the political old guard.

If that happens, it seems likely that the biggest winner will not be Ranil Wickremesinghe â€“ who is reported to be suffering from several health challenges and has not indicated whether he is returning to politics â€“ but rather a scion of the Rajapaksas. That increasingly appears to be Mahinda Rajapaksaâ€™s active, colourful, and controversial son Namal.

Read more on Scroll.in (Link in BIO/IG STORIES)

#Srilankapolitics #ranilwickremesinghe #ranilwickremesinghearrest

It is not quite a miracle. But it is certainly a very impressive turnaround. From around 1970 until 2021, Sri Lanka seemed to be on an irreversible track toward steadily worsening governance: grand corruption, disregard of the law, ethnic and religious conflict, state violence and (non-military) government incapacity and incompetence. Today, by contrast, following the September 2024 presidential and the November 2024 parliamentary elections, the prospects for more substantive democracy and better governance seem bright.

The old political elite and the broader politician class have been replaced almost completely through the most peaceful and fair elections that the country has seen for a long time. The prospect of military intervention in politics has entirely faded. The female proportion of MPs doubled from a very low 5% in a year when the global trend was in the other direction.

The new National Peopleâ€™s Power government, with 67% of parliamentary seats, shows every sign of intending to reduce corruption, obey the law, respect expertise, negotiate political solutions to pressing problems and generally rule in accord with the instincts of the educated, middle class professionals who provide so much of its ideological and organisational heft. 

Mick Moore analyses structural and historical causes and explains what brought about a hopeful change in Sri Lanka.

Continue reading on Scroll.in [Link in Bio]

#srilanka #srilankapolitics #srilankaeconomiccrisis #srilankanewgovernment #AnuraKumaraDissanayake

Former President Ranil Wickremesinghe has been arrested by the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) over allegations of misusing state funds during his presidency from 2022 to 2024.

The charges stem from a September 2023 trip to London, where Wickremesinghe attended his wifeâ€™s graduation ceremony at the University of Wolverhampton.
